title: 107_hr5198
content: The Act may be cited as the "Premier Certified Lenders Program Improvement Act of 2002". The Premier Certified Lenders Program (PCLP) has successfully helped small businesses expand. Increasing the number of premier certified lenders will provide more resources to small businesses as the Small Business Administration downsizes. However, the PCLP requires lenders to set aside large amounts in loss reserve accounts. Premier certified lenders should maintain loss reserve accounts based on the risk associated with PCLP loans, allowing for more efficient lending to small businesses. The risk of loss associated with PCLP loans will protect taxpayers and enhance the program's ability to support small businesses in economic development. SEC. 3. ALTERNATIVE LOSS RESERVE FOR CERTAIN PREMIER CERTIFIED LENDERS. SEC. 3 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 introduces an alternative loss reserve option for qualified high loss reserve PCLs, allowing them to elect to follow specific requirements in place of others for a given calendar quarter. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 offers an alternative loss reserve option for qualified high loss reserve PCLs, allowing them to elect specific requirements for a calendar quarter without making contributions to their loss reserve during that quarter. Companies must make necessary contributions to their loss reserve based on the risk of loss before the end of the quarter. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 provides an option for qualified high loss reserve PCLs to maintain a loss reserve of at least $25,000, determined by a third-party auditor, to protect the Federal Government from the risk of loss associated with their PCLP loan portfolio. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows premier certified lenders to maintain a qualified high loss reserve PCL of at least $25,000, based on risk analysis of their PCLP loan portfolio. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 allows premier certified lenders to maintain a qualified high loss reserve PCL to protect the Federal Government from the risk of loss associated with their PCLP loan portfolio, certified by a third-party auditor quarterly.
